SecureFedYJ: a safe feature Gaussianization protocol for Federated Learning

Abstract

The Yeo-Johnson (YJ) transformation is a standard parametrized per-feature unidimensional transformation often used to Gaussianize features in machine learning. In this paper, we investigate the problem of applying the YJ transformation in a cross-silo Federated Learning setting under privacy constraints. For the first time, we prove that the YJ negative log-likelihood is in fact convex, which allows us to optimize it with exponential search. We numerically show that the resulting algorithm is more stable than the state-of-the-art approach based on the Brent minimization method. Building on this simple algorithm and Secure Multiparty Computation routines, we propose SecureFedYJ, a federated algorithm that performs a pooled-equivalent YJ transformation without leaking more information than the final fitted parameters do. Quantitative experiments on real data demonstrate that, in addition to being secure, our approach reliably normalizes features across silos as well as if data were pooled, making it a viable approach for safe federated feature Gaussianization.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL)Â [45, 32] is an approach that was recently proposed to train machine learning (ML) models across multiple data holders, or clients, without centralizing data points, notably for privacy reasons. While many FL applications have been proposed, two main settings have emerged [23]: cross-device FL, involving a large number of small edge devices, and cross-silo FL, dealing with a smaller number of clients, with larger computational capabilities. Due to the sensitivity and relative local scarcity of medical data, healthcare is a promising application of cross-silo FLÂ [40], e.g.Â to train a biomedical ML model between different hospitals as if all the datasets were pooled in a central server. In this paper, we focus on the cross-silo setting.

The constraints of cross-silo FL

Although cross-silo FL resembles standard distributed learning, it faces at least two important distinct challenges: privacy and heterogeneity. Due to data sensitivity, clients might impose stringent security and privacy constraints on FL collaborations. This arises in coopetitive FL projects, where models are jointly trained on industrial competitorsâ€™ datasetsÂ [55], as well as medical FL applications, where conservative data regulations might apply. In this setting, using standard FL algorithms such asÂ FedAvgÂ [32] might not provide enough privacy guarantees, as privacy attacks such as data reconstruction can be carried out based on the clientsâ€™ gradientsÂ [56, 54]. Various protocols based on Secure Multiparty ComputationÂ (SMC) (see SectionÂ 2 for more details), such as Secure AggregationÂ [4], can mitigate this shortcoming by disclosing only the sum of the gradients from all clients to the server, without disclosing each gradient individually.

An additional constraint is that data might present statistical heterogeneity across clients, i.e.Â the local clientsâ€™ data distributions may not be identical. In the case of medical applications, such heterogeneity may be caused e.g.Â by environmental variations or differences in the material that was used for acquisitionÂ [43, 47, 2]. While different ways of adapting federated training algorithms have been proposed to automatically tackle heterogeneityÂ [28, 29, 24], these solutions do not address data harmonization and normalization prior to FL training.

Preprocessing in ML

Data preprocessing is a crucial step in many ML applications, leading to important performance gains. Among others, common preprocessing methods include data whitening, principal component analysis (PCA)Â [22] or zero component analysis [27, 20, 46]. However, linear normalization methods might not suffice when the original data distribution is highly non-Gaussian. For tabular and time series data, a popular approach to Gaussianize the marginal distributions is to apply feature-wise non-linear transformations. Two commonly-used parametric methods are the Box-Cox [5] transformation and its extension, the Yeo-Johnson (YJ) transformation [52]. Both have been used in multiple applications, such as climate and weather forecastÂ [53, 50, 51], economicsÂ [13] and genomic studiesÂ [7, 58, 9].

Problem and contributions

In this paper, we investigate the problem of data normalization in the cross-silo FL setting, by exploring how to apply the YJ transformation to a distributed dataset. This problem arises frequently in medical cross-silo FL, e.g.Â when trying to jointly train models on genetic data (see e.g. [19, 57]). Due to data heterogeneity, no single client can act as a reference client: indeed, there is no guarantee that transformation parameters fitted on a single client would be relevant for other clientsâ€™ data. Hence, it is necessary to fit normalization methods on the full federated dataset. Moreover, in this setting, data privacy is of paramount importance, and therefore FL protocols should be carefully designed. Our main contributions to this problem are as follows:

  1. 1.

    We prove that the negative YJ log-likelihood is convex (SectionÂ 3), which is a novel result, to the best of our knowledge.

  2. 2.

    Building on this property, we introduce ExpYJ, a method to fit the YJ transformation based on exponential search (SectionÂ 3). We numerically show that this method is more stable than standard approaches for fitting the YJ transformation based on the Brent minimization method [6].

  3. 3.

    We propose SecureFedYJÂ (SectionÂ 4), a secure way to extend ExpYJÂ in the cross-silo FL setting using SMC. We show that SecureFedYJÂ does not leak any information on the datasets apart from what is leaked by the parameters minimizing the YJ negative log-likelihood (SectionÂ 4 and PropositionÂ 4.1). By construction, SecureFedYJÂ provides the same results as the pooled-equivalent ExpYJ, regardless of how the data is split across the clients. We check this property in numerical experiments (SectionÂ 4). The core ideas behind the resulting algorithm, SecureFedYJ, are summarised in FigureÂ 7.

Finally, we illustrate our contributions in numerical applications on synthetic and genomic data in SectionÂ 5.

2 Background

The Yeo-Johnson transformation

The YJ transformation [52] was introduced in order to Gaussianize data that can be either positive or negative. It was proposed as a generalization of the Box-Cox transformation [5], that only applies to non-negative data. The YJ transformation consists in applying to each feature a monotonic function Î¨â€‹(Î»,â‹…)Î¨ğœ†â‹…\Psi(\lambda,\cdot) parametrized by a scalar Î»ğœ†\lambda, independently of the other features. Minimization methods in dimension 1

As seen above, fitting a YJ transformation can be reduced to a 1D optimization problem. To tackle this problem, we introduce two standard 1D minimization methods: (i) Brent minimization [6] and (ii) exponential search [3].

Brent minimization [6] (not to be confused with the Brent-Dekker method, see [6], chapters 3 and 4) is a widely used method for 1D optimization. It is based on golden section search and successive parabolic interpolations, and does not require evaluating any derivatives. This algorithm is guaranteed to converge to a local minimum with superlinear convergence of order at leastÂ 1.3247. Standard implementations of the YJ transformation, in particular the scikit-learn implementation [36], are based on the Brent minimization method to minimize the negative log-likelihood provided by Eq.Â (3).

Exponential search [3] is a dichotomic algorithm designed for unbounded search spaces. The idea is to first find bounds, and then to perform a classic binary search within these bounds. This algorithm can be used to find the minimum of convex differentiable functions with linear convergence, as explained in AppendixÂ B. In this work, we build on exponential search to propose a federated version of the YJ transform, for two main reasons: (i) it is more numerically stable than Brent minimization, as shown in SectionÂ 3 and FigureÂ 2, (ii), it may conveniently be adapted to a federated setting, as shown in SectionÂ 4, and (iii), this latter federated adaptation offers strong privacy garantees, as shown by PropositionÂ 4.1.

Secure Multiparty Computation

As illustrated by various privacy gradient attacks [56, 54], sensitive information on the clientsâ€™ datasets can be leaked to the central server during an FL training. One way to mitigate this risk is to use Secure Multiparty Computation (SMC) protocols to hide individual contributions to the server. SMC enables one to evaluate functions with inputs distributed across different users without revealing intermediate results and is often based on secret sharing. SMC protocols tailored for ML use-cases have been recently proposedÂ [12, 14, 34, 39, 48, 33, 49, 41]. These protocols are either designed to enhance the privacy of FL trainings, or to perform secure inference, i.e.Â to enable the evaluation of model trained privately on a server without revealing the data nor the model.

A popular FL algorithm relying on SMC is Secure Aggregation (SA)Â [4]. Schematically, in SA each client adds a random mask to their model update before sending it to the central server. These masks have been tailored in such a way that they all together sum to zero. Therefore, the central server cannot see the individual updates of the clients, but it can recover the sum of these updates by adding all the masked quantities sent from them.

More generally, an SMC routine schematically works as follows (we refer to AppendixÂ D for further details). Let us consider the setting where Kğ¾K parties k=1,â€¦,Kğ‘˜1â€¦ğ¾k=1,\dots,K want to computeÂ g=fâ€‹(h(1),â€¦,h(K))ğ‘”ğ‘“superscriptâ„1â€¦superscriptâ„ğ¾g=f(h^{(1)},\dots,h^{(K)}) for a known function fğ‘“f, where (h(1),â€¦,h(K))superscriptâ„1â€¦superscriptâ„ğ¾(h^{(1)},\dots,h^{(K)}) denote private inputs. Each partyÂ kğ‘˜k knows h(k)superscriptâ„ğ‘˜h^{(k)} and is not willing to share it. During the first step, secret sharing, each party splits its private input h(k)superscriptâ„ğ‘˜h^{(k)} into K secret shares h1(k),â€¦,hK(k)subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ¾h^{(k)}_{1},\dots,h^{(k)}_{K}, and sends the shares hkâ€²(k)subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜â€²h^{(k)}_{k^{\prime}} to the partyÂ kâ€²superscriptğ‘˜â€²k^{\prime}. These secret shares are constructed in such a way that (i) knowing hkâ€²(k)subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜â€²h^{(k)}_{k^{\prime}} does not provide any information on the value of h(k)superscriptâ„ğ‘˜h^{(k)}, and (ii) h(k)superscriptâ„ğ‘˜h^{(k)} can be reconstructed from the vector (h1(k),â€¦,hK(k))subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ¾(h^{(k)}_{1},\dots,h^{(k)}_{K}). For simplicity, we denote âŸ¦h(k)âŸ§=(h1(k),â€¦,hK(k))\llbracket h^{(k)}\rrbracket=(h^{(k)}_{1},\dots,h^{(k)}_{K}) the vector of share secrets. In a second step, the computation, each party kâ€²superscriptğ‘˜â€²k^{\prime} computes the quantity denoted gkâ€²subscriptğ‘”superscriptğ‘˜â€²g_{k^{\prime}} using the secret shares they know along with intermediate quantities exchanged with the other parties. The way to compute gkâ€²subscriptğ‘”superscriptğ‘˜â€²g_{k^{\prime}} depends on fğ‘“f and on the SMC protocol that is used, and is chosen so that g=fâ€‹(h(1),â€¦,h(K))ğ‘”ğ‘“superscriptâ„1â€¦superscriptâ„ğ¾g=f(h^{(1)},\dots,h^{(K)}) can be reconstructed from (g1,â€¦â€‹gK)subscriptğ‘”1â€¦subscriptğ‘”ğ¾(g_{1},\dots g_{K}). Said otherwise, gkâ€²subscriptğ‘”superscriptğ‘˜â€²g_{k^{\prime}} are secret shares of gğ‘”g: âŸ¦gâŸ§=(g1,â€¦gK)\llbracket g\rrbracket=(g_{1},\dots g_{K}). Finally, during the reveal step, each party kğ‘˜k reveals gksubscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜g_{k} to all other parties, and each party can reconstruct gğ‘”g from (g1,â€¦â€‹gK)subscriptğ‘”1â€¦subscriptğ‘”ğ¾(g_{1},\dots g_{K}).

Threat model

In this work, we consider an honest-but-curious settingÂ [35]. Neither the clients nor the server will deviate from the agreed protocol, but each party can potentially try to infer as much information as possible using data they see during the protocol. This setting is relevant for cross-silo FL, where participants are often large institutions whose reputation could be ternished by a more malicious behaviour.

3 A novel method to optimize the Yeo-Johnson log-likelihood: ExpYJÂ 

In this section, we leverage the convexity of the negative log-likelihood of the YJ transformation (see PropositionÂ 3.1) to propose a new method to find the optimal Î»âˆ—subscriptğœ†\lambda_{*} using exponential search. While this method only offers linear convergence, compared to the super-linear convergence of Brent minimization method, we demonstrate two of its advantages: (i) it is more numerically stable, and (ii) it is easily amenable to an FL setting with strong privacy guarantees. The method proposed in this section is based on the following result.

Proposition 3.1.

The negative log-likehood Î»â†¦âˆ’logâ¡â„’YJâ€‹(Î»)maps-toğœ†subscriptâ„’YJğœ†\lambda\mapsto-\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}(\lambda) (3) is strictly convex.

The proof of PropositionÂ 3.1 builds upon the work of [26] which shows that the negative log-likelihood of the Box-Cox transformation [5] is convex. The complete proof is deferred to AppendixÂ C.

Due to the strict convexity of the negative log-likelihood of the YJ transformation, we may perform the exponential search described in SectionÂ 2 and AppendixÂ B. Accuracy of ExpYJ

We check the accuracy of ExpYJÂ on the datasets presented in SectionÂ E.1. In particular, we compare the results provided by ExpYJÂ with the outputs of the scikit-learn algorithm based on Brent minimization.

For 2 of the 108 features present in the datasets, the scikit-learn implementation leads to numerical instabilities discussed hereafter. Therefore, we focus our comparison on the 106 remaining features, that we aggregated regardless of the dataset. FigureÂ 2 reports the relative difference Î´â€‹Î»ğ›¿ğœ†\delta\lambda between the results obtained by ExpYJÂ and by the scikit-learn implementation as a function of the number of iteration tmaxsubscriptğ‘¡maxt_{\mathrm{max}} (as defined in AlgorithmÂ 1). These results show that this relative difference is of order less than Â 10âˆ’6superscript10610^{-6} when tmax=40subscriptğ‘¡max40t_{\mathrm{max}}=40.

Numerical stability of ExpYJ

Our experiments demonstrate that ExpYJÂ is numerically more stable than Brent minimization. Indeed, for some values of Î»ğœ†\lambda and some datasets {xi}subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\{x_{i}\}, the transformationÂ Î¨â€‹(Î»,â‹…)Î¨ğœ†â‹…\Psi(\lambda,\cdot) concentrates all data points in a small interval such that the values of Î¨â€‹(Î»,{xi})Î¨ğœ†subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\Psi(\lambda,\{x_{i}\}) are all equal up to machine precision. This instability happens for 2 of the 108 features used in numerical experiments, where blindly applying the Brent-based YJ transformation leads to all data points collapsing to zero, while ExpYJÂ succeeds in transforming the data distributions to more Gaussian-like ones. SectionÂ E.4 shows that this issue also arises in other real-life datasets.

4 Applying the Yeo-Johnson transformation in FL

So far, we only considered the centralized setting, where data is accessible from a single server. Yet, as mentioned in SectionsÂ 1 andÂ 2, many real-world situations require working with heterogeneous data split between different centers, and to take privacy constraints into account. When the data is split across centers k=1,â€¦,Kğ‘˜1â€¦ğ¾k=1,\dots,K and the function to optimize is separable, i.e.Â of the form â„±â€‹(Î»)=âˆ‘k=1Kfkâ€‹(Î»)â„±ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğœ†\mathcal{F}(\lambda)=\sum_{k=1}^{K}f_{k}(\lambda) where each fksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜f_{k} can be computed from data present in the center kğ‘˜k exclusively, Federated Learning techniques were recently proposed. In short, they consist in repeatedly performing a few rounds of local optimization in each center, before aggregating local parameters in the server. We refer toÂ [23] for an overview of recent advances in FL. In our case, however, the YJ negative log-likelihood (3) is not separable, due to the log-variance term. Indeed, turning the variance into a separable term would require sharing the global YJ meanÂ Î¼Î»subscriptğœ‡ğœ†\mu_{\lambda} to all centers at each iteration. Compared to the method we propose in this section, this would lead to more privacy leakage.

We now introduce SecureFedYJ, a secure federated algorithm that builds upon ExpYJÂ to apply YJ transformations. This algorithm satisfies the two following properties: (i) it is pooled-equivalent, i.e.Â it yields the same results as if the data were freely accessible from a single server, and (ii) it leaks as little information as possible about the underlying datasets, as shown by PropositionÂ 4.1. Finally, it converges in a limited number of iterations, thanks to the linear convergence of the underlying exponential search.

SecureFedYJ

SecureFedYJÂ is a federated adaptation of ExpYJÂ presented in SectionÂ 3 to find the best parameters (Î»âˆ—,Î¼âˆ—,Ïƒâˆ—2)subscriptğœ†subscriptğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğœ2(\lambda_{*},\mu_{*},\sigma_{*}^{2}) of the YJ transformation when training datasets are split across different clients. It relies on SMC to ensure that only the final tripletÂ (Î»âˆ—,Î¼âˆ—,Ïƒâˆ—2)subscriptğœ†subscriptğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğœ2(\lambda_{*},\mu_{*},\sigma_{*}^{2}) fitted on the training datasets is revealed, without leaking any other information apart from the overall total number of training samples nğ‘›n. Indeed, at each intermediate step, only the sign of âˆ‚Î»logâ¡â„’YJsubscriptğœ†subscriptâ„’YJ\partial_{\lambda}\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}} is revealed, and the mean and variance of the transformed data is only revealed at the last step. The pseudo-code of the resulting algorithm is presented in AlgorithmÂ 3, and relies on the exponential search presented in AlgorithmÂ 2. A functional representation of SecureFedYJÂ is displayed FigureÂ 7.

As introduced in SectionÂ 2, we use double brackets âŸ¦â‹…âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§â‹…\llbracket\cdot\rrbracket to indicate an SMC secret shared across the clients (see AppendixÂ D for more details).

Privacy leakage

In PropositionÂ 4.1 we show that AlgorithmÂ 3 only reveals information already contained in the fitted triplet (Î»âˆ—,Î¼âˆ—,Ïƒâˆ—2)subscriptğœ†subscriptğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğœ2(\lambda_{*},\mu_{*},\sigma_{*}^{2}). In comparison, turning the YJ negative log-likelihood (3) into a log-separable function before using off-the-shelf FL methods would require sharing Î¼ğœ‡\mu and its gradient and centrally computing Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} for intermediate values of Î»ğœ†\lambda at each iteration. This could potentially lead to uncontrolled privacy leakage.

Proposition 4.1.

The fitted parameter Î»âˆ—subscriptğœ†\lambda_{*} contains all the information revealed during the intermediate steps of SecureFedYJ. More precisely, there exists a deterministic function â„±â„±\mathcal{F} such that for any set of datasets {xk,i}subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘–\{x_{k,i}\} , if Î»âˆ—â€‹({xk,i})subscriptğœ†subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘–\lambda_{*}(\{x_{k,i}\}) is the result of SecureFedYJÂ on {xk,i}subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘–\{x_{k,i}\}, thenÂ {Î»t,Î»t+,Î»tâˆ’,Î”t}t=1,â‹¯,tmax=â„±â€‹[Î»âˆ—â€‹({xk,i})]subscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘¡subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1â‹¯subscriptğ‘¡maxâ„±delimited-[]subscriptğœ†subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘–\{\lambda_{t},\lambda^{+}_{t},\lambda^{-}_{t},\Delta_{t}\}_{t=1,\cdots,t_{\mathrm{max}}}=\mathcal{F}\left[\lambda_{*}(\{x_{k,i}\})\right]

Proof. This proposition comes from the fact that all gradient signs Î”tsubscriptÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta_{t} revealed during the algorithm can be retrospectively inferred from Î»âˆ—subscriptğœ†\lambda_{*}. Indeed,Â âˆ‚Î»logâ¡â„’YJ<0subscriptğœ†subscriptâ„’YJ0\partial_{\lambda}\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}<0 for Î»>Î»âˆ—ğœ†subscriptğœ†\lambda>\lambda_{*} and âˆ‚Î»logâ¡â„’YJ>0subscriptğœ†subscriptâ„’YJ0\partial_{\lambda}\log\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}>0 forÂ Î»<Î»âˆ—ğœ†subscriptğœ†\lambda<\lambda_{*}. Performance of SecureFedYJ

We implement SecureFedYJÂ in Python, using the MPyC library [42] based on Shamir Secret Sharing [44]. We refer to AppendixÂ D for more details on our implementation. To represent signed real-valued numbers in an SMC protocol, we use a fixed-point representation (see SectionÂ D.2) using lğ‘™l bits, among which fğ‘“f bits are used for the decimal parts. This means that we consider floats ranging fromÂ âˆ’2lâˆ’fsuperscript2ğ‘™ğ‘“-2^{l-f} toÂ 2lâˆ’fsuperscript2ğ‘™ğ‘“2^{l-f} and that we have an absolution precision of 2âˆ’fsuperscript2ğ‘“2^{-f} in our computations.

In order to ensure the accuracy of SecureFedYJÂ results, we need to make sure that lğ‘™l and fğ‘“f are large enough. FigureÂ 3 shows the accuracy of SecureFedYJÂ when compared to ExpYJÂ for various values ofÂ fğ‘“f. According to these numerical experiments, takingÂ f=50ğ‘“50f=50 andÂ l=100ğ‘™100l=100 provides reasonably accurate results. Moreover, by construction, the outputs of SecureFedYJÂ do not depend on how the data is split across the clients, up to rounding numerical errors. Therefore this algorithm is resilient to data heterogeneity, as long as the numerical decimal precision fğ‘“f is large enough, as shown in FigureÂ 3.

Performing SecureFedYJÂ withÂ tmax=40subscriptğ‘¡40t_{\mathrm{\max}}=40 takes 726 rounds of communication (see SectionÂ D.6). During these communication rounds, each client sends overall about 8Â Mb per feature to every other client (see also SectionÂ D.6). SecureFedYJÂ can be applied independently and in parallel to each feature. Therefore, the overall number of rounds does not depend on the number of features being considered, and the communication costs grow proportionally to the number of features. In a realistic cross-silo FL setting as described in [19], the bandwidth of the network is 111Â Gb per second with a delay ofÂ 20â€‹ms20ms20\ \mathrm{ms} between every two clients. In this context, the execution of SecureFedYJÂ withÂ tmax=40subscriptğ‘¡40t_{\mathrm{\max}}=40 on pğ‘p features would take about 726Ã—20â€‹msâ‰ƒ15â€‹ssimilar-to-or-equals72620ms15s726\times 20\ \mathrm{ms}\simeq 15\ \mathrm{s} due to the communication overhead, in addition to pÃ—8â€‹Mb/1â€‹Gbpsâ‰ƒ8â€‹pâ€‹mssimilar-to-or-equalsğ‘8Mb1Gbps8ğ‘msp\times 8\ \mathrm{Mb}/1\ \mathrm{Gbps}\simeq 8p\ \mathrm{ms} due to the bandwidth. This shows that SecureFedYJÂ is indeed a viable algorithm in a real-world scenario.

As pointed out in AppendixÂ B, the binary search in the exponential search can be replaced by a kğ‘˜k-ary search. In such a setting, the sign of the negative log-likelihood of the YJ transformation is computed for kâˆ’1ğ‘˜1k-1 different values of Î»ğœ†\lambda at each round. Such a modification would reduce the number of communication rounds required to obtain a given accuracy, while increasing the size of the data exchanged over the network at each round.

5 Applications

Genomic data: TCGA

We start by showing the benefits of YJ preprocessing in survival analysis experiments on lung (LUAD+LUSC), pancreas (PAAD), and colorectal (CRC) cancers. Given gene expression raw counts (features) and censored survival data (responses) from patients having either of those three cancers, we aim to fit a Cox Proportional Hazards (CoxPH) modelÂ [10] with the highest possible concordance index (C-index)Â [25], which measures how well patients are ranked with respect to their survival times. We refer toÂ [25] for a more thorough introduction to survival analysis. In FigureÂ 4, we compare three different preprocessing methods: (i) whitening, (ii) log normalization, and (iii) YJ, each followed by a PCA dimensionality reduction step. More precisely, whitening (i) consists in centering and reducing to unit variance the total read counts of all genes across all samples, log normalization consists in applying uâ†¦logâ¡(1+u)maps-toğ‘¢1ğ‘¢u\mapsto\log(1+u) to raw read counts before applying global whitening, and YJ is a global YJ transform on the total read counts. We then evaluate each strategy using 5-fold cross-validation with 5 different seeds. We refer to SectionÂ E.2 for experimental details. While this experiment is performed in a pooled environment, note that, importantly, each step has a federated pooled-equivalent version: apart from the proposed SecureFedYJÂ for YJ, see e.g. [21] for PCA, and WebdiscoÂ [31] for Cox model fitting. This simplified setting allows us to understand the importance of the Yeo-Johnson transformation in an ideal setting, independently of other potential downstream federated learning artifacts.

In FigureÂ 4, we see that YJ is better or on par with the best method for each cancer: YJ improves prediction results for colorectal cancer, while yielding results which are on par with the best results for lung and pancreas cancers, with a smaller variance.

Synthetic data

We show how applying YJ may help improving performance compared to no or basic preprocessing, and how SecureFedYJÂ yields improvements compared to local YJ transforms in federated linear regression. To do so, we generate covariates X~~ğ‘‹\widetilde{X} and responses yğ‘¦y as

Hence, we expect that applying a suitable preprocessing step before training a linear model will transform back the X~isubscript~ğ‘‹ğ‘–\widetilde{X}_{i}â€™s into the normally-distributed Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}â€™s and lead to a high performance, compared to no transformation. The results of our experiments are summarized in FigureÂ 5. The left figure shows that the YJ transformation is indeed capable of roughly inverting theÂ X~isubscript~ğ‘‹ğ‘–\widetilde{X}_{i}â€™s into theÂ Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}â€™s, yielding a major improvement compared to no preprocessing or standard centering and reduction to unit variance. Besides, the right figure shows that even in this homogeneous setting where the data is i.i.d.Â across centers, using a federated version of YJ compared to a local version of YJ leads to better average performance, and reduced variance.

6 Conclusion

Summary of our contributions

In this work, we introduce SecureFedYJ, a method to fit a YJ transformation on data shared by different clients in a cross-silo setting. SecureFedYJÂ is an SMC version of its pooled equivalent ExpYJâ€‰ which builds upon the convexity of the negative log-likelihood of the YJ transformation, a novel result introduced by this work, and on the fact that the sign of its derivative can be computed in a stable way. We show that SecureFedYJÂ has the same accuracy as a standard YJ transformation on pooled data. In particular, the results do not depend on how the data is split across the clients, making SecureFedYJÂ resilient to data heterogeneity. Besides, the quantities disclosed by SecureFedYJÂ during the training to the central server do not leak any other information than what is contained in the final parameters (Î¼âˆ—,Î»âˆ—,Ïƒâˆ—2)subscriptğœ‡subscriptğœ†subscriptsuperscriptğœ2(\mu_{*},\lambda_{*},\sigma^{2}_{*}).

Limitations and future work

While Brent minimization has a super-linear convergence, our approach only has a linear convergence, as it relies on exponential search. This can be an issue if the communication costs between the clients and the server are high. Acceleration could be achieved by either adapting Brent minimization to a cross-silo setting, or applying a second-order method. We leave the development of a faster SMC methods using either of those two approaches to future work.

Another limitation is that even if our approach reveals only information that would be contained in the final fitted parameters, such parameters themselves might leak information about individual samples, as our approach is not differentially private (DP)Â [16]. By adding Gaussian or Laplacian noise to each sampleâ€™s features when computing theÂ Sgsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘”S_{g} terms one could, in principle, make the resulting algorithm DPÂ [1]. However it is unclear to what extent the noise would impact the final accuracy of the method.

Finally, we only consider an honest-but-curious setting. We do not explore the threat of a malicious participant that would purposely deviate from the protocol to either gain more information or to jeopardize the convergence. We leave this investigation to future work.

A.2 Relationship with the Box-Cox transformation

The Box-Cox transformation [5] works similarly to the YJ transformation, but only applies to strictly positive data. The Box-Cox transformation is based on a function Î¦â€‹(Î»,â‹…)Î¦ğœ†â‹…\Phi(\lambda,\cdot) parametrized by Î»ğœ†\lambda and defined for x>0ğ‘¥0x>0 as:

It is straightforward to check that for any Î»âˆˆâ„ğœ†â„\lambda\in\mathbb{R} the YJ transformation Î¨Î¨\Psi and the Box-Cox transformation Î¦Î¦\Phi are related by the following equations:

Appendix B Background on exponential search

Exponential searchÂ [3] is a method to look for an element in an unbounded sorted array. The idea is to first find bounds on the array such that the element is contained within such bounds, and then perform a classic binary search inside these bounds. Let us consider the task of finding the smallest elementÂ ui0subscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘–0u_{i_{0}} greater than a threshold Cğ¶C in an unbounded sorted arrayÂ {ui}iâˆˆâ„•âˆ—subscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘–superscriptâ„•\{u_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}^{*}}. The exponential search iteratively looks at uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} for iâˆˆ{1,2,22,24,â€¦}ğ‘–12superscript22superscript24â€¦i\in\{1,2,2^{2},2^{4},\dots\} until it finds a imaxsubscriptğ‘–maxi_{\mathrm{max}} such thatÂ uimaxâ‰¥Csubscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘–maxğ¶u_{i_{\mathrm{max}}}\geq C. This takes log2â¡(imax)subscript2subscriptğ‘–max\log_{2}(i_{\mathrm{max}}) steps. Then it performs a binary search between i=imax/2ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–max2i=i_{\mathrm{max}}/2 and i=imaxğ‘–subscriptğ‘–maxi=i_{\mathrm{max}}, which also takes log2â¡(imax/2)subscript2subscriptğ‘–max2\log_{2}(i_{\mathrm{max}}/2) steps.

If fâ€‹(s)ğ‘“ğ‘ f(s) is a strictly increasing function of sğ‘ s taking both positive and negative values, one can adapt the exponential search to find the root s0subscriptğ‘ 0s_{0} of fğ‘“f. The first step is to find an upper and a lower bound of s0subscriptğ‘ 0s_{0} by evaluating fğ‘“f at different points using an exponential grid (e.g.Â evaluatingÂ fğ‘“f inÂ s=1,âˆ’1,2,âˆ’2,22,âˆ’22,24,âˆ’24,â€¦ğ‘ 1122superscript22superscript22superscript24superscript24â€¦s=1,-1,2,-2,2^{2},-2^{2},2^{4},-2^{4},\dots). Once such bounds are found, one can perform a dichotomic search inside these bounds to find the root s0subscriptğ‘ 0s_{0} of fğ‘“f. This dichotomic search has a linear convergence of order 222, with each step summarized in AlgorithmÂ 2. It is important to note that this algorithm is correct even if fğ‘“f is not increasing, as long asÂ fâ€‹(s)<0ğ‘“ğ‘ 0f(s)<0 whenÂ s<s0ğ‘ subscriptğ‘ 0s<s_{0} andÂ fâ€‹(s)>0ğ‘“ğ‘ 0f(s)>0 whenÂ s>s0ğ‘ subscriptğ‘ 0s>s_{0}, as is the case in this work when fğ‘“f is the derivative of the negative YJ log-likelihood.

FigureÂ 6 is an illustration of ExpYJÂ that is based on exponential search.

A natural extension of the exponential search is to replace the binary search into a kğ‘˜k-ary search during the dichotomic search. In that case, kâˆ’1ğ‘˜1k-1 values of fğ‘“f are computed at each round. Such a modification reduces the number of steps required for a given accuracy while increasing the number of operations performed at each step.

C.4 Strict convexity of the Yeo-Johnson negative log-likelihood.

To prove the strict convexity of the YJ negative log-likelihood, let us notice that under the hypotheses of LemmaÂ C.1, if at least one function Î»â†¦lnâ¡(fi)maps-toğœ†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\lambda\mapsto\ln(f_{i}) is strictly convex, then Î»â†¦lnâ¡[âˆ‘ifiâ€‹(Î»)]maps-toğœ†subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğœ†\lambda\mapsto\ln[\sum_{i}f_{i}(\lambda)] is strictly convex. The only problematic case is when both ÏƒÎ±2=0subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ›¼0\sigma^{2}_{\alpha}=0 and ÏƒÎ²2=0subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ›½0\sigma^{2}_{\beta}=0. Appendix D Secure Multi-Party Computation

D.1 Shamir Secret Sharing

Secure Multiparty Computation (SMC) consists in evaluating functions without disclosing their inputs. One way to achieve this result is to use secret sharing. The main idea is that a value hâ„h is split into different secret shares hksubscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{k}, k=1,â‹¯,Kğ‘˜1â‹¯ğ¾k=1,\cdots,K where Kğ¾K is the number of clients. Each client kğ‘˜k only knows the value of the secret share hksubscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{k}, and one needs at least pğ‘p shares with 1<pâ‰¤K1ğ‘ğ¾1<p\leq K to recover the initial value hâ„h. The set of the secret shares hksubscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{k} of hâ„h is denoted âŸ¦hâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§â„\llbracket h\rrbracket. Schematically, SMC consists in three main steps: (i) secret sharing, where each client splits its input into secret shares and sends them to the other clients (ii) computation, where the clients perform mathematical computations on the secret shares and obtain secret shares of the output and (iii) reveal steps, where the clients send each other the secret shares of the output in order to reconstruct and reveal the output.

In the Shamir Secret Sharing method [44], the secret shares of hâ„h correspond to the values of a given polynomial Phâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘ƒâ„ğ‘¥P_{h}(x) of order Kğ¾K at different points xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} where Phâ€‹(0)=hsubscriptğ‘ƒâ„0â„P_{h}(0)=h. The values xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} are arbitrarly chosen by the protocol with the constraint that all xksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{k} should be distinct. If all the clients disclose their secret share hk=Phâ€‹(xk)subscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒâ„subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜h_{k}=P_{h}(x_{k}), then the secret hâ„h can be recovered by polynomial interpolation. In this framework the addition can be done trivially. If âŸ¦hâŸ§={hk}k=1,â‹¯â€‹K\llbracket h\rrbracket=\{h_{k}\}_{k=1,\cdots K} and âŸ¦gâŸ§={gk}k=1,â‹¯â€‹K\llbracket g\rrbracket=\{g_{k}\}_{k=1,\cdots K} are the shares of gğ‘”g, then âŸ¦g+hâŸ§={gk+hk}k=1,â‹¯â€‹K\llbracket g+h\rrbracket=\{g_{k}+h_{k}\}_{k=1,\cdots K} are shares of g+hğ‘”â„g+h. Said otherwise, âŸ¦g+hâŸ§=âŸ¦gâŸ§+âŸ¦hâŸ§\llbracket g+h\rrbracket=\llbracket g\rrbracket+\llbracket h\rrbracket. Therefore adding two shared secrets requires no communication between the clients. Similarly, multiplying a shared secret by a public constant cğ‘c is done without communication as âŸ¦cgâŸ§=câŸ¦gâŸ§\llbracket cg\rrbracket=c\llbracket g\rrbracket. However, multiplying two shared secrets, i.e.Â computing shares of âŸ¦gâ€‹hâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘”â„\llbracket gh\rrbracket is more involved and requires one round of communication. More precisely, each client has to send one scalar quantity to all the other clients during this process, as explained for example in [37], section 3.

D.2 Fixed-Point Representation

The secret shares in SMC belong to a finite set â„¤psubscriptâ„¤ğ‘\mathbb{Z}_{p} where pğ‘p is a prime number and all the operations are integer operations done modulo pğ‘p. In practice we consider integers encoded using lğ‘™l bits, then we choose the smallest prime number pğ‘p such that 2l<psuperscript2ğ‘™ğ‘2^{l}<p and we perform each operation modulo pğ‘p. Therefore any value has to be encoded as an integer using a finite number of bits. To encode negative integers, we consider that encoded integers between 00 and 2lâˆ’1âˆ’1superscript2ğ‘™112^{l-1}-1 are positive and encoded integers between 2lâˆ’1superscript2ğ‘™12^{l-1} and 2lâˆ’1superscript2ğ‘™12^{l}-1 are negative. We have to choose a value of lğ‘™l large enough such that the highest absolute value considered is below 2lâˆ’1superscript2ğ‘™12^{l-1}. Real-value numbers are encoded using fixed-point precision, as described in [8], where the fğ‘“f least significant bits of the encoding correspond to the decimal part, and the lâˆ’fğ‘™ğ‘“l-f most significant bits correspond to the integer part. The addition of two fixed-point numbers in SMC can be done as described in SectionÂ D.1. However, multiplying two fixed-point representation numbers in SMC is more complex as the result must be divided by 2fsuperscript2ğ‘“2^{f}, i.e.Â the 2fsuperscript2ğ‘“2^{f} least significant bits are discarded. As explained in detail in [8], multiplying two fixed-point numbers requires two rounds of communication (instead of one round of communication for the multiplication of two integers).

D.3 Comparison in SMC

In SecureFedYJÂ , we need to compute in SMC the sign of an expression, which is equivalent to making a comparison with 00. As we are using fixed-point representation encoding, computing the sign amounts to computing the most significant bit of the binary decomposition of a given shared secret. In order to do so, we use the method described in [38], which works for any SMC framework supporting addition and multiplication. This method requires 101010 rounds of communication among the clients (666 of which can be done offline, i.e.Â they correspond to random values exchanged beforehand and can be done regardless of the value of the input). During these 10 rounds of communication,Â 153â€‹l+423â€‹logâ¡l+24153ğ‘™423ğ‘™24153l+423\log l+24 multiplications are performed, 135â€‹l+423â€‹logâ¡l+16135ğ‘™423ğ‘™16135l+423\log l+16 of which can also be done offline. Notice that other SMC primitives could be used, such as the one described in [17] which provides more efficient way to do SMC comparison.

D.4 MPyC

To implement SecureFedYJÂ we used the python library MPyC [42]. MPyC is based built upon VIFF framework [11] and is based on Shamir Secret Sharing [44]. We refer to [30] for a discussion of the performance of this library for various SMC tasks.

D.6 Complexity of SecureFedYJÂ 

At each step of the exponential search, we share 6 secrets (the values of Sgsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘”S_{g}), perform 10 fixed-point multiplications (including multiplying and dividing by nğ‘›n), and one comparison (i.e.Â computing the sign of âˆ‚Î»â„’YJsubscriptğœ†subscriptâ„’YJ\partial_{\lambda}\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{YJ}}.

The 6 secrets can be shared in parallel in one round of communication. Some of the multiplications can also be done in parallel, and only 3 successive rounds of multiplications have to be performed, which require 6 rounds of communications. As stated in SectionÂ D.3, the comparison requires 10 rounds of communications. Revealing the secret Î”Î”\Delta also requires one round of communication. Notice that the additions do not require any round of communication. This amounts to 181818 communications per exponential search step. Besides, computing âŸ¦SÏ•âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ‘†italic-Ï•\llbracket S_{\phi}\rrbracket at the beginning of the algorithm and computing and revealing Î¼âˆ—subscriptğœ‡\mu_{*} and Ïƒâˆ—2subscriptsuperscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}_{*} at the end of the algorithm requires 6 more rounds of communication. Overall, performing 404040 steps of exponential search with SecureFedYJÂ costs 18Ã—40+6=7261840672618\times 40+6=726 rounds of communications.

For each elementary operation, such as sharing a secret, revealing a secret or making a multiplication, the order of magnitude of the size of the message sent by each client to the other clients is âŒˆlog2â¡(p)âŒ‰subscript2ğ‘\lceil\log_{2}(p)\rceil bits. Notice that log2â¡(p)subscript2ğ‘\log_{2}(p) is of the same order of magnitude of lğ‘™l as pğ‘p is the smallest prime number aboveÂ 2lsuperscript2ğ‘™2^{l}. More precisely, each client sends around lğ‘™l bits to each of the other clients for these elementary operations. The overall size of the messages exchanged during the 726 rounds of communications mentioned above is mainly dominated by the 153â€‹l+423â€‹logâ¡l+24153ğ‘™423ğ‘™24153l+423\log l+24 multiplications done at each of the 40 comparisons. Taking l=100ğ‘™100l=100, we find that each client sends overall aroundÂ 6.5 107superscript6.51076.5\ 10^{7} bits (or âˆ¼8similar-toabsent8\sim 8 Mega-bytes) to each of the other clients during SecureFedYJ.

Appendix E Details of the numerical experiments

E.1 Datasets used in this work

Datasets exposed by scikit-learn API used in FigureÂ 2 and FigureÂ 3

For numerical experiments, we use four public datasets available in the UC Irvine Machine Learning repository [15] under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) license and exposed by the scikit-learn datasets API. These datasets are the Iris dataset [18] (150 samples, 4 features), the Wine Data Set (178 samples, 13 features), the Optical Recognition of Handwritten Digits Data Set (1797 samples, 64 features) and the Breast Cancer Wisconsin (Diagnostic) Data Set (569 samples, 30 features). Only keeping features that have at least two distinct values, these datasets provide a total of 108 different features.

Extra UC Irvine Machine Learning repositories used to test Brent minimization method

Genomic data used in FigureÂ 4

For genetic experiments, we rely on RNA-seq expression data from The Cancer Genome Atlas, expressed in Fragments per Kilobase Million (FPKM). We focus on 3 cancers: colorectal cancer (COAD), lung cancer (LUAD + LUSC), and pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PAAD). These datasets are available on https://portal.gdc.cancer.gov/ under Open Access.

E.2 Experiments on TCGA data

Based on FPKM counts, we load all available data for each cancer of interest, removing genes with null expression for all samples.

Pipeline

Our pipeline consists of three steps:

  1. 1.

    Normalization: either whitening, log, or Yeo-Johnson transformation;

  2. 2.

    Dimensionality reduction: a PCA was applied on normalized data to reduce dimension (dimension 128128128 for lung and colorectal cancer, 909090 for pancreatic cancer);

  3. 3.

    Cox Proportional Hazards (CoxPH)Â [10] model fitting.

Normalization

All normalization steps are performed on counts, regardless of the genes, as counts are related to the same underlying phenomenon induced by next-generation RNA sequencing. In other words, for the plain whitening, a single mean and variance is computed. For log, following application of log(1+â‹…)\log(1+\cdot) to all entries, a similar count-level whitening is performed. For the YJ transformation, we perform 101010 iterations of the proposed algorithm.

CoxPH model training

CoxPH models are fitted with lifelines (0.26.4). We use an â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} regularization of magnitude 101010 for each cancer, without any hyperparameter optimization.

Cross-validation

Results are computed following 555-fold stratified group cross-validation, repeatedÂ 555 times with different seeds. Stratification is performed to ensure a balanced set of censored patients in each fold, while ensuring that samples belonging to the same patients end up in the same group to avoid over-estimating the generalization of the model.

E.3 Experiment on synthetic data

To generate the results of FigureÂ 5, we sampled for each of the 10 centers 200 datapoints using Eq.Â (6). We then apply an optional preprocessing steps before fitting a linear regression model using scikit-learn LinearRegression model on the pooled data. Another dataset of 200 points was then generated, and we computed the R2 on this unseen dataset. This experiment was repeated 1000 times using each time a different seed and the box plot in FigureÂ 5 presents the min-max, the median the first and the third quartile. The different preprocessing steps shown are:

  • â€¢

    None: no preprocessing step is applied

  • â€¢

    Whitening: for each of the three dimensions of Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}, we subtract the empirical mean and we divide by the empirical standard deviation computed across all ten centers to the train dataset and the test dataset

  • â€¢

    LocalYJ: we use one center randomly chosen to perform ExpYJÂ with tmax=20subscriptğ‘¡max20t_{\mathrm{max}}=20 to each of the dimensions of the dataset. The fitted triplets Î»âˆ—,Î¼âˆ—,Ïƒâˆ—2subscriptğœ†subscriptğœ‡subscriptsuperscriptğœ2\lambda_{*},\mu_{*},\sigma^{2}_{*} found for each column are then used to normalize the dataset of all 10 centers and the test dataset.

  • â€¢

    Federated YJ: We apply SecureFedYJÂ with tmax=20subscriptğ‘¡max20t_{\mathrm{max}}=20 on the 10 centers to each of the dimensions of the dataset. The fitted triplets Î»âˆ—,Î¼âˆ—,Ïƒâˆ—2subscriptğœ†subscriptğœ‡subscriptsuperscriptğœ2\lambda_{*},\mu_{*},\sigma^{2}_{*} found for each column are then used to normalize the dataset of all 10 centers and the test dataset.

E.4 Testing Brent minimization on more dataset

As explained in the paragraph Numerical stability of ExpYJ of SectionÂ 3, applying blindly the Brent minimization method of scikit-learn to minimize the Yeo-Johnson negative log-likelihood might result in numerical instabilities and might collapse all the values of the dataset into a single value. To check further whether this phenomenon is likely to appear, we apply the scikit-learn Yeo-Johnson transformation to various real-life tabular datasets of the UC Irvine Machine Learning repository [15] (which are under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International, CC BY 4.0). For each dataset, we only kept the features that have at least two distinct values. We found that for the 484 fetaures out of 24 datasets, this issue arises 5 times, as summarized by TableÂ 1

PropositionÂ 4.1 states that all intermediate quantities of SecureFedYJÂ can be recovered from its final result Î»âˆ—subscriptğœ†\lambda_{*}. We provide in AlgorithmÂ 4 a way to construct the function â„±â„±\mathcal{F} introduced in PropositionÂ 4.1 that can perform this recovery.

We apply AlgorithmÂ 4 on the 108 features used in FigureÂ 3, with a fixed-point precision of f=50ğ‘“50f=50. We numerically check that the output of â„±â„±\mathcal{F} from AlgorithmÂ 4 matches the intermediate quantities revealed by AlgorithmÂ 3 up to machine precision.
